name: jonathan dryer
text: This place is definitely a hidden gem. Wow!!! It a difficult hike down hill and up hill but this waterfall was amazing the multiple waterfall after a good rain I can imagine are super amazing coming off the canyon walls. The water coming out of the rock that makes the waterfall is super cool if you can get up close to it on a dry spell it's doable. It is a true 6.8 miles round trip the hike back is what is the hardest. Follow the red trail when you get to the valley follow the second creek to waterfall Clark Cemetery

name: Dylan Woessner
text: This was a long trip. Took about 5 hours from start to finish. Well worth the work though. Lots of great scenery to view and the end point is a great destination.

name: Rick Cooper
text: Awesome! Well worth the long hike. Plan on spending the entire day. The hike back is all uphill.

name: The Bearded Man-Drenaline
text: Was an epic Hike-a-bike! Obviously I couldn't bike all of it, that's where the hike comes in, some of the best views these eyes have seen. The difficulty level depends on the state of your health and fitness, as a healthy 35 year old, I would call it moderate, well worth it, next time I wont bring the bike but it was worth the challenge! Always a blessing to be able to enjoy YHWH's beautiful creation🙌

name: Bartholomew Roland
text:
This is a stunningly beautiful trail that ends with a waterfall tucked behind a golden amphitheater of stone.

The trail is a difficult hike. You will go nearly 1,300ft down and back up the ravine. The trail can be nearly 6-7 miles in length if you push all the way to the back of the gorge (out + back). There are also plenty of places to step off the trail and do some exploring. The stoney riverbanks were a ton of fun to pick around and added some extra joy and length to our trip.

The trailhead here has two handicap accessible portable toilets for those in need, and the gravel parking lot is right off a paved road. There are no trash receptacles, you'll need to pack out. This trail is easy to get to from the highway.

name: Lyndsay MacPhee
text: This is a beautiful place! It took us about 4 hours to hike. The trail is well marked with red blazes on trees about every 10 feet or so. If you are hiking at dusk or at night, be sure to look for them closely on the switchback portion of the trail. There are two log bridges to cross, currently being replaced with sturdier concrete and steel bridges. The trail is very steep at points and is also pretty narrow. Make sure to bring plenty of water!! The horseback riding trail crosses the foot hiker trail twice. Once you cross the second bridge, you can choose to go along the top of the Walls of Jericho or go into the Walls of Jericho. My group opted to go into the Walls. It is definitely worth the hike!! It's very awe inspiring to be inside. Make sure to enjoy it while you're there!! This is a great day hike!!

name: Michael Turner
text: Excellent Trail! Be warned though, it is not for the meek. Definitely no strollers. I recommend taking a walking stick. It is approximately two hours to the waterfall from the Alabama parking area. (Dependant on how fast you walk) Follow the red paint on the trees, it is very clearly marked! There is no bathroom or water fountain at the waterfall, go prepared.

name: Tim Moore
text:
This place is definitely worth a visit. Plan for a whole day.  The relatively short distance is more than made up for by the steep elevation change.

If you do want to camp out, there are several designated campsites on the trail.

name: Tim Moore
text:
This place is definitely worth a visit. Plan for a whole day.  The relatively short distance is more than made up for by the steep elevation change.

If you do want to camp out, there are several designated campsites on the trail.

name: D Boyd
text: Walls of Jericho is one of my favorite places to hike in Alabama. My first trip was over 40 years ago. Each season provides something different. The large rock formation near the falls at the very north point is amazing. In many ways it is a very unique formation for this area. The hike out is a challenge and a good training exercise for even bigger hikes. This is one of those hikes where you should make an effort to be prepared. I have shared water with much younger hikers that thought they could hike in and back without water in July?! I recommend you make the side trip to see where Mill Creek (which you pass on the way to the Walls) originates from a hole in the rocks east of the trail.

name: Liz Rogers
text: I hiked here October 3, 2020 from the Alabama side, as part of a spiritual cleaning and as a reward to myself for loosing 130lbs. I had never been on a hike before in my life and I was a little scared, but I spent about a month getting physically and mentally prepared for it. I had done alot of research and studying the trail too. I also studied some on the Walls of Jericho story in the Bible which helped enhance my experience on the trail. It was a beautiful, religious and an amazing experience! However, this hike is not for the faint of heart and it is not your regular walk in the park. I highly recommend taking a hiking stick, being physically and mentally prepared and wearing comfortable clothes and hiking shoes or boots. It took me about 8 hours to hike roundtrip, of course I took my time since I wasn't used to the trail and wanted to take in as much as I could. Bring plenty of snacks and water and a couple bottles of Powerade. After I completed the hike, I gave up my right to never complain about anything ever again and include more gratitude in my life. This hike was also a teacher in a way. I will definitely do it again!

name: Darren Scott
text: 3.5 miles and you will need to cross ankle deep water to get to the bigger falls. Beautiful!!

name: Dennis Dickson
text: Nice hike, I wish the signs had direction arrows on them.

name: Wil Bowman
text: Best hike in Alabama, hands down. Traveling light, an experienced hiker should be able to make the round trip in 3 hours. The first three miles are also really good for trail running. It can get crowded, so you have to hit it early in the busy season.

name: Eric Cameron
text: Beautiful hike! Start early!!

name: Howard Smithey, Sr
text: Awesome! A 'must-do' for the avid hiker.

name: Rob Easter
text: Moderate hike: All down hill going to the Walls but all uphill coming back so be prepared for that.

name: Karol Gawrych
text: The walls of Jericho hike is designated as difficult, but my wife and I found it to be moderate at best. It is log, taking about 3 hours round trip and has a long uphill climb on the return trip, but it is a gradual ascent. Nothing a little patience and will power cannot overcome! The views and tranquility are well worth the effort.

name: Rob Daugherty
text: It's worth the long walk.  The return walk of 2 miles mostly UPHILL can be difficult. Give yourself extra time for slower return.  ALSO... Be warned, the South Rim trail does NOT circle around to the beautiful end like the trailhead map shows.  You have sort of a view through the trees (no, it isn't worth the hike) but then you come to a red blazed END.  I tried hiking further as there is a slight trail, but it soon just turns into nothing.  You can bravely trudge through the forest (surely coming to a cliff face) or turn around and walk the plus-mile back.  Stay to your right when you see the South Rim sign.  It's beautiful and I didn't want to leave.

name: Chris Lett
text:
This is a place of sanctuary. A long rewarding walk.  This trail is down hill on the way to the water hole. On the way back you are going up hill so make sure you are prepared.

My dog and I hiked this trail during mid July and It was miserably hot with no wind chill so getting to the water hole was very rewarding. If you hike trail first thing in the morning you will make it to the trail by the evening. So if you plan on hitting the water hole before the sun sets make sure you start early.

If you use a Garmin GPS there are a few check points and marked points for sites of interest (You're Welcome).

The trail was a bit confusing at some points due to missing signs.  Good ole American flags someone else planted before me helped guide the way during confusing intersecting points. I took note of this for future hikes and I will always carry markers with me and for others in the future.

I hope to hike this trail in the Fall one day so I can see all the creeks filled with water instead of a dried up creeks... Overall 5 star from me and my furry friend.

name: Nancy Forshaw
text: Beautiful place and pleasant hike down. Going back up is VERY strenuous. It's a 1,000 feet elevation from the top of the trailhead down to the creek.

name: Holly Owens
text: Absolutely beautiful!! Longest hike I've been on but definitely worth it!

name: Dennis Dickson
text: Nice hike, I wish the signs had direction arrows on them.

name: Karol Gawrych
text: The walls of Jericho hike is designated as difficult, but my wife and I found it to be moderate at best. It is log, taking about 3 hours round trip and has a long uphill climb on the return trip, but it is a gradual ascent. Nothing a little patience and will power cannot overcome! The views and tranquility are well worth the effort.

name: Wil Bowman
text: Best hike in Alabama, hands down. Traveling light, an experienced hiker should be able to make the round trip in 3 hours. The first three miles are also really good for trail running. It can get crowded, so you have to hit it early in the busy season.

name: Olivia Buchanan
text: Amazing hike, but definitely strenuous. It's downhill going in so that's pretty easy, but it's all uphill on the way back out which is where it gets exhausting. We got a little lost so make sure you cross 2 tree bridges and take the path by the barbed wire which will lead you along a steep rocky hillside. The sight of the water pool waiting for you at the end is breathtaking!

name: Howard Smithey, Sr
text: Awesome! A 'must-do' for the avid hiker.

name: Ryan Fogg
text:
Its going to take the average hiker 2.5 - 3 hours to get in +30 minutes at the falls to explore, then another 2.5 - 3 hours back out.
Cliff notes:
Extremely wet and slippery in spots especially after recent rain
Bring water shoes for falls area
Plenty of water (at least 2L/person) and food
Poison ivy is EVERYWHERE along the trails (miles of it) be extremely vigilant if allergic
Lots of giant millipedes (Apheloria virginiensis corrugate)
AL trailhead is red, horse trail is white. They will cross each other frequently, pay attention to the marks.  Watch out around the campground area and don't accidentally go on the South Rim Trail, stay near the barbed wire/pink flagged trees which is the trail.

name: Justin Lacey
text: A good long hike, the switch backs help out a lot though. Hiked with a 5&6 year old and they did great but we walk hills pretty often.  Beautiful place, I do wish people would pick up after themselves better though. I'll probably check it out again in the fall

name: Matthew Sims
text: Beautiful place! We loved taking our hammocks and camping out for a few days. Worth the hike and climb to see the fall.

name: Nancy Forshaw
text: Beautiful place and pleasant hike down. Going back up is VERY strenuous. It's a 1,000 feet elevation from the top of the trailhead down to the creek.

name: Wallace Kistler
text: Great hike - popular place!

name: Ella White
text: Awesome place for hiking with the whole family

name: Rob Daugherty
text: It's worth the long walk.  The return walk of 2 miles mostly UPHILL can be difficult. Give yourself extra time for slower return.  ALSO... Be warned, the South Rim trail does NOT circle around to the beautiful end like the trailhead map shows.  You have sort of a view through the trees (no, it isn't worth the hike) but then you come to a red blazed END.  I tried hiking further as there is a slight trail, but it soon just turns into nothing.  You can bravely trudge through the forest (surely coming to a cliff face) or turn around and walk the plus-mile back.  Stay to your right when you see the South Rim sign.  It's beautiful and I didn't want to leave.

name: Ryan Fogg
text:
Its going to take the average hiker 2.5 - 3 hours to get in +30 minutes at the falls to explore, then another 2.5 - 3 hours back out.
Cliff notes:
Extremely wet and slippery in spots especially after recent rain
Bring water shoes for falls area
Plenty of water (at least 2L/person) and food
Poison ivy is EVERYWHERE along the trails (miles of it) be extremely vigilant if allergic
Lots of giant millipedes (Apheloria virginiensis corrugate)
AL trailhead is red, horse trail is white. They will cross each other frequently, pay attention to the marks.  Watch out around the campground area and don't accidentally go on the South Rim Trail, stay near the barbed wire/pink flagged trees which is the trail.

name: John Beckett
text: This is an awesome hike! There are details elsewhere, I won't get into them here.

name: Jasper Montgomery
text: This is such an amazing place to hike! With beautiful scenery

name: David Molvik
text: Great place to hike. This hike gets the heart pumping.

name: Holly Owens
text: Absolutely beautiful!! Longest hike I've been on but definitely worth it!

name: Vacations Alabama
text: Such a beautiful trail.

name: Nathon Roden
text: This is a local spot for me. I've hiked it at night and day. The second waterfall is crazy cool. But of a rough one. Carry water.

name: Alex K
text: Be prepared for a hike!! Lots of legwork to get to the falls, but definitely worth it. This trail is rated hard by alltrails, rei, and other places. Do your research and pack accordingly. But I had a magical day down at the water.

name: William Sciaroni
text: As experienced hikers, we hiked there and back just under 3-hours. With an hour to explore, our overall trip took 4 hours. We were in good shape, so these are not going to be typical times.  Do not attempt this without Plenty of water. We each consumed about 3 Liters.  If you are inexperienced or not in top shape, I would say this hike could take you 5-6 hours round trip. Be prepared and stay safe.

name: Peter McCoy
text: Great hike.  Took about 4 hours with plenty of time to enjoy the falls.  The hike out may be difficult for young children or people that aren't in shape.  Plan for 5-6 hours if you think you may need multiple rest breaks.  It's not Niagra falls but it is impressive when there is a lot of water flowing.  It is especially interesting how the river has disappears into the canyon wall at the base of the falls to reemerge downstream.  Great thing about the trail is that there are plenty of things to see other than the falls.

name: Heath Varmette
text: The water hole is amazing

name: Andrew Rodriguez
text: A somewhat strenuous hike, but a serene payoff.

name: Jacob Mcdaniel
text: Beautiful area for hiking and photography. Long trail but was worth it.

name: Bobby Walton
text: Awesome place 😊

name: Marc Compton
text: It is great place to hike that pushes your limits and great sites to see throughout the entire hike.

name: MicusIII
text: A super beautiful and amazing trail. I would recommend it to everyone!

name: Chris
text: Neat trail

name: Stephen Glass
text: Awesome waterfall!

name: Steven Hughes
text: Awesome place. Highly recommend.

name: Richard York
text: It was a nice hike..

name: Bethany Hart
text: Definitely a difficult hike but if you prepare mentally and bring plenty of water it's beyond rewarding!!

name: Mr. Hyde
text:
The hike back up from the waterfall to the parking lot was an hour and a half.

Gorgeous colors with the sunlight
You will have to take your shoes off or else they will get wet. There is ankle deep water that is almost impossible to go around.

name: Jaky Suarez
text: Whatever you do!!!! If you are walking do not take the horse trail also if you’re coming from the Scottsboro side please do not make the mistake my group and I did do get off in the first Parking lot, my group and I got lost and even almost got bitten by a rattle snake. And to top it off we did not find the waterfall and walked 7 hours being lost. It is Very easy to veer off the trail so please pay attention!!

name: Tammy McKendree
text: Nice place to walk nature trails. They also have horse trails. It's free to visit here. The older lady at the desk was very helpful and nice.

name: Justine Vild
text: If you need some really good exercise and are in relatively good shape, do this hike. It took us about 3h15 total with some very brief stops along the way and about a 15 min break enjoying the "walls". We were moving though. You will need at least 3 water bottles per person during the hot summer months. More if you drink a lot while you hike. Pay attention to the red markers because there are a few confusing spots. You hike down with a steep hike up at the end to get to the "walls" which is a small waterfall/roccky stream area. The way back up can be brutal. I haven't done this in a year or two and I was hoping the end was just up the next hill but then there were 7 more hills after every last hill. Lol Great, challenging hike though. After I forget how hard it was, I'll do it again. 😉

name: Christy Isbell
text: Very long and I would rate moderate to difficult trail that winds down a mountain side. Plan to walk 4plus hours. Take plenty of water/ a lunch and snacks. I do not recommend this trail for small children.

name: Flooding Rivers
text: OMG!!!!! Not for the novice.  We took a group of 8, 4 children (8-12) and 4 adults. We started out way too late and it took 6 hours instead of the 4 we estimated.  2 hours in the pitch black during a MONSOON (which came out of nowhere with no warning) was nothing short of TERRORIZING!!  Fortunately we all lived, but rivers come out of nowhere when the rain falls.  Steep cliffs, very rocky.  A day and night we won't soon forget!  The only thing missing was bigfoot!

name: Jason Sides
text:
Love this place but not for the faint at heart or someone that's not physically fit to walk a distance.
The trails can be quite demanding but definitely worth the hike if you can handle it.
Great for younger folks who love nature

name: Joe Schmoe
text:
Easy then tough then tougher.
Turn around
Real tough, easier then real tough to finish.

name: Mahnorreah ChinHun
text: Strenuous hiking trail. Make sure to walk on the pathway. Some kids got lost when we were there,  and one kid broke his ankle while trying to cut through.  Going downward was okay but hiking back up, oh man! I had fun and enjoyed it.

name: Cameron Nickle
text: Great trail. Beautiful site at the bottom. Took my dog and I about 3 hours round trip. But be warned you're going down hill when you start out and up hill on your way back to the parking lot. It's a lot easier to to the falls than it is coming back.

name: Thom Wells
text: Beautiful hike.   Lovely forest

name: Jackson Buckner
text: Bring food, and plenty of water, because once you get to the spring at the walls itll be hard to want to leave. Bring what you need to stay as long as you can.

name: Jennifer Cruz
text: Amazing place but it's a very very difficult hike bring lots of snack and water and pack lightly expect to hike for at least 6 -7 hours with a almost 8 mile long round trip to the hike

name: Brandon Saltzmann
text: When the state says its gonna take you at least 6 hours to hike this. Please don't go 2 hours before nightfall. I did and we had to walk a random road for 2.4 miles. At one point we had been followed by some animals in the woods. The hike was awesome though as were always looking for the thrill. We went swimming too and it was freezing cold. I recommend taking a lot of water and maybe a snack or two. But my brothers and I are adventurous so we had nothing but our clothes and shoes. 5 stars definitely will be going back. This hike was just amazing!!

name: Marty Couey
text: Great scenery, well marked trail, excellent exercise.  The walk back out is taxing. Give yourself time if you aren't in great shape.

name: Steve Parsons
text: Advise-go prepared. We did this hike on a whim and got educated. The hike took us longer than expected and we had to almost race back up the mountain before it got dark. Will go back again when more time.

name: Patricia Kerins
text: This is definitely NOT  a beginner trail! However  it is AWESOME!! Worth the hike for sure!

name: Chris Davis
text: Great hike! Camped at the camp site at the bottom, best solo camp site so far. Wonderful having the whole place to myself,  hiked to the falls the next day. Falls wasn't running but still awesome with the spring flowing out. I climbed up to the walls of Jericho falls and I can imagine its beautiful with some water but definitely would add to the danger of get there.The climb by out was a pretty long climb but definitely worth it all. Be careful in the off season coming by, It was easy to get turned around when u crossing over the horse trail. Give yourself time for the climb out, take alot of breaks and you got this. Pack in, pack out!

name: Gottfried Kibelka
text:
Please don't underestimate the 1000 feet gain in elevation over the last 2 miles of the hike.  I've done the hike in summer at 90 F  and just the other day at 40 F. I do prefer winter time. With no leaves you have a much better view and the hike back and up to the trailhead is so much easier when it's not as hot. In summer 2 L of water was not enough for me, in winter I only drank 0.5 L.
Go after rain, the creeks and waterfalls are much more impressive. Bring a walking stick, the trail can be very slick after rain. Bring water shoes if you want to safely cross the creek at the waterfall and you might want to bring a hammock to relax in the trees close to the waterfall.
Most importantly: Leave no trace!! Campers don't always see the need to pack their trash out and I am highly annoyed when I see slightly burned cans in a fire ring. I can get pretty mad when people believe that they must chop down a living tree because they didn't collect enough dead wood before they started a fire. Freshly cut trees will smoke but not burn (unless you have a strong fire anyways). Since I am on my soapbox:  Wear waterproof boots and step into puddles on the trail. Walking around the puddle only widens the trail and increases the muddy area.

name: John Buckelew
text: Absolutely beautiful. The 4 mile hike down 1000 ft to the Walls are worth the pain of the 4 mile hike up 1000 ft.

name: Joseph Drury
text: Definitely not a hike for those who cant walk for ling periods. Gorgeous landscape near the water.

name: Chris Reid
text: Very nice trailhead for backpackers. There is a Porta-potty in the parking lot, and there is a basic Campground a few hundred meters from the lot. The trail is well marked, and it is about 4 miles to the falls. The hills are somewhat steep, so be prepared and bring water.

name: Paula Stewart
text: Great hike! Need to be really prepared for hike and take plenty of water. Tough hike

name: Mary T
text: This is a really beautiful place. Took 4 kids ages 9-14 and did it in a little over 5 hours including an hour to play and picnic at the falls. Would not consider it a “hard” trail if you’ve done much hiking outside of AL. But pretty sure it is more than 6 miles. Had such a great time and Wish we had planned a longer day or overnight. Red blazes were not very evident the last half mile or so but it’s just one trail and stays along the water at the end.   Be sure to go all the way to the end, across and up past the first falls.

name: Amanda Foster
text: My oh my was it a hot day. But great hike with a nice cold pool at the bottom

name: Scotty Tucker
text: Very difficult hike to the Walls of Jerricho but it is very rewarding.  It is a 6.6 mile round trip hike to the waterfall. There is port a potties at the parking lot. There is tent camping at the parking lot.

name: Sharon Kilzer
text: Wonderful trail, great swimming hole

name: Jennifer Thomas
text: Beautiful hike but not for the faint of heart.  Very difficult hike and must be cautious after it has rained cause it is very slippery.

name: Satish Vedula
text: Definitely one of the toughest hikes! Took around 4 hrs to go to the Wall and back.Waterfalls was so beautiful. Make sure you carry enough water as the return journey from the falls is gonna be rough!

name: Nikolai Claud
text: Awesome hike. The hike out was super strenuous, but we decided to just walk straight up the hills instead of taking the trail. We went when the water was up, and it was really cool. I need to go back.

name: phyllis larson
text: Challenging

name: C W
text: A hike for the experienced, and well worth it. Leave nothing but footprints, take nothing but memories!

name: Bryan Tauchen
text: Pretty trail with great waterfall at end. Out and back, not much loop option. Remember that you start by dropping about 700 ft. You need to climb that 700 feet.

name: Leland Campbell
text: great trail, best afew days a after good rain to get the water level up. if you're not an experienced hiker allow at least 6 hours

name: Amy Dubois
text: A difficult hike but it was beautiful!

name: Melissa Marsh
text: Gorgeous destination. Easy hike in, but all uphill on the way back. Several interesting sights on the trail. Saw a good many fellow hikers, which can be good or bad depending on how you feel about such.

name: Rotten Candy
text: So much fun! Alot of hard walking but worth it. Even my 5 year old finished it and back

name: Kristi Tahada
text:
If you're not in shape, like me, this trail will take everything you have and then some. Going down is challenging but well worth it to see the walls, the little waterfalls, and the caverns. The water was really cold but we got in anyway. Coming back up? BRUTAL! I cried, I screamed, got debilitating leg cramps. Did I mention it's brutal?

Be sure to wear covering clothes because the trail is very narrow in places and you will be brushing up against foliage (some of which has thorns), climbing over and under fallen trees, and navigating mud pits. Take plenty of water and food. Stretch. Write your will. Have fun lol

name: Ellen George
text: Make sure you come prepared!!!! This is a difficult hike so bring adequate food and water. The last two miles back to your car are straight uphill and it is extremely boring. Also I recommend going after a heavy rain. When we went there wasnt much of a waterfall at the end.

name: Tanner Godfrey
text: Fun trail and beautiful destination. The cascades and falls in the canyon are amazing and definitely worth the hike. Note of caution: come prepared (water, fitness, good shoes, etc.) It's an easy hike down but three miles up-hill going out. We saw several people really struggling coming out. Also careful on the falls. We saw two people slip and go over the drop (10 feet); luckily they missed the shallow rock shelf.

name: Robert Flowers
text: This was an excellent hike today. I highly recommend hiking at this beautiful place. It is a strenuous hike,  it is best to leave plenty of time for the adventure.

name: alex davis
text: Grew up in these woods, cultivated the land in these woods, better have strong legs to make this trip it is no joke you hike down a mountain, and up a creek bed, is the best way to hike this. Best time to go is a few days after a good rain when the water is still flowing out of the mountain. Nice swimming hole to cool you off, extremely cold and clear water. Have at least a gallon of water per person(for the trip in) another gallon for the trip out. Very old cemetery in the valley before the ascent to the walls along with a primitive campground for tents and small campfires. The hurricane creek is teeming with different aquatic life if you venture down the creek with a fishing pole you can catch some of the best tasting fish you've ever eaten. Again this isn't a beginners trail and there are plenty of wildlife in those woods, snakes included. After your endeavor to the walls is complete the hike out is up the mountain so be prepared to get winded. Worth the hike, worth the workout, take it from someone who has been in those woods for 20 years. Good luck

name: Ty Reed
text: Always a beautiful hike, no matter what time of year you visit.

name: Melody 123
text: BRING LOTS OF WATER AND ELECTROLYTE DRINKS VERY HARD HIKE BUT BEAUTIFUL SWIM HOLE AT THE BOTTOM

name: Tony Alexander
text: Beautiful. And good exercise.

name: Bill P.
text: Best hike ever....I dont know what some of you whiners are complaining about. This trail is not that difficult, compared to many out west. Put your big boy and girl panties on and enjoy the beauty. Several people who appeared to be handicapped handled the trail just fine. It was 7 miles round trip, but it was far from difficult compared to some we have done. It also helps if you bring a bottle of wine or your favorite adult beverage to enjoy at the pool at the bottom.

name: Jed Park
text: Great experience.  Everyone who can go (it's an 8 mile hike with significant elevation changes) should go.

name: Gary Moore
text: Great place to go. Went for my son's 27th birthday. Grulling 6 hours, but great. Saw people starting their decent at 3:00. Hope they got out before dark. Did I say it was great? Where are my Epsom salts?

name: Chip Ferrell
text: Pretty cool place. Went in from Alabama trail head. Hiked straight  down for 3 miles. The Walls are really cool to check out. The 3 mile hike out is the same trail going up. Take what you need and leave the cry babies at home. Overall I had 8 miles on the nose when I finished. I recommend carrying a water bottle.

name: Scott Staton
text: Absolutely a beautiful place carved into the hills. The hike in and out is a bear because the depth of the canyon. The trail is in excellent shape, just a lot of it.

name: Seth Allison
text: Decent graveled parking lot with space for ~25 cars.

name: Chris Fears
text: 1st parking lot, coming from Woodville is for horseback riding trail, 1 mile torwards TN is foot trailhead.

name: Wayne
text: This is not an easy or well marked trail.  But it's beautiful.  Six mile hike (round trip), 1500 elevation change.

name: Dan Anderson
text: Great, but strenuous hike.  Excellent for both day hikes and overnight backpacking camp.  Bring at least 2qts of water (or a filter)

name: W3 S33 33
text: This trail is NOT for the faint of heart, but it is beautiful!  Take a friend or twi,

name: Chuck Bryant
text: Tough trail but raining and muddy, hell. It will test you. Go try it.

name: Dustin Walker
text: Loved it. Wasn't a very hard hike but challenging.

name: Colleen Costigan
text: Hard trail but very fun. Would be good for packing

name: Hunter Henson
text: Wonderful, Beautiful place. Nice place to get away for a few hours and experience the wilderness.

name: Justin Loyd
text: Great hiking spot in North Alabama, right on the Alabama Tennessee border. Very cool trail that is challenging and fun.

name: Nicky Beale
text: A very pretty but challenging hike. Make sure to bring snacks and water.

name: Michael Willis
text: It's longer than 3 miles, but beautiful.

name: rico hartman
text: Am amazing place.

name: Tamyeria Dickson
text: According to the website this is a 6.7 mike hike which is very incorrect. We took our 3 daughters ages 14 to 23. When I got to the bottom I collapsed and we were told it would take 5-10 hours for help to arrive by horseback. On that way back everyone was so scared and nervous. We hike. We’re not rookies at this. We’ve done many things that are considered a difficult hike. This was by far the most dangerous hike we’ve ever been on. Rattle snakes everywhere and just a terrible path with loads of dangerous things and accidents waiting to happen.

name: tim lowe
text: It was hell...very unforgiving.  I will never forget this day.

name: Jeanie Collins
text: Great hike!

name: Nathan Allen
text: A great place for a day hike. There is a also nice place to take a dip mid way through the hike. If you can arrange it, hiking from the Tennessee trailhead to the Alabama Trailhead is a good way to see the area, you will need two vehicles to drop one off at the destination trailhead.

name: Jesse Smith
text: Beautiful hike and worth the effort to get back up the hill!

name: David Lindsey
text: Awesome trail, the waterfall almost isn't worth the 3 mile hike. But the scenery on the way there was great.

name: jennyferfaithhope
text:
We walked two miles in and never found the river  :(  Bring a trail map.
Quite beautiful.

name: Edward Jimenez
text: Great hike! Great camping sites.

name: Jason Agee
text: Great hike have been here twice first trip done an overnight second trip spent 2 nights will be back again

name: William Evans
text: we went on Alabama side it's a good thing to do but make sure you have water and in good shape

name: Joe Parks
text: Walls are amazing, thou it was really crowded for backpacking on an weekend in November

name: Candi Bickers
text: Fun and beautiful. Much more difficult hike than you will expect.

name: Johanna Stevens
text: Very difficult hike after about the first mile.

name: J B
text: Cool trail, very long. Need the whole day off to hike.

name: madelyn breeding
text: such a beautiful place to be. it may be a tough hike going back up but the end view is so worth it!

name: Mik S
text:
Great public land access
Land trust needs to add some latrines at bottom and have trash pickup in campground area

name: Justin Quinn
text: Very nice hike, great views. Make sure to take plenty of water and snacks.

name: LaJarvis Provins
text: Nice hike!!

name: Teresa Baldwin
text: Long trails love it.

name: Kayla Underwood
text: Long hike

name: Tommy Lee
text: Great day hike.

name: Melissa Dutton
text: This is one of my go to places to hike becuse its so close to home

name: MLChampion
text: Hard hike but worth it

name: Jaeryong Park
text: No water in creek and falls

name: John Beckett
text: I've already done this.

name: Robert Whiddon
text: Be prepared

name: Randy Hamilton
text: Long trail.

name: Ben Nelson
text: Fantastic hike.

name: Charles Batchelor
text: Awsome during the winter months

name: Gypsy Wind
text:
(Translated by Google) Great hikei go often

(Original)
Great hikei go often

name: That One Dude
text: Really good trails! Beautiful views. A good workout for the legs and pet friendly, so that's a bonus. We took our cats on a walk and they loved it!

name: Ben Whitson
text: Fantastic hiking spot with plenty of parking. Some friends and I spent 4 days 3 nights hiking around and camping. The south side is beautiful and a fairly easy hike. It has nice views of some water feature too. The north side starts with a bit of a climb and water isn't found for a while unless you hike down a very steep section off trail. All in all a fantastic place to spend either the day or a whole weekend.

name: Mollie Waters
text: Plentybof parking, but you'll have to share it with the hunters during hunting season. They are always nice, though.

name: Jeff Buckingham
text: Dugger Mountain, Great place to hike, moderate challenge

name: Jason Jackson
text: Gateway to the Dugger wilderness.   A great spot for a southbound hike yo Choccoloco lake or north into the Dugger wilderness.

name: beverly hamilton
text: One of my favorite things to do is hike! This place is a great hiking trail! Beautiful Land!

name: Ferrell Moultrie
text: Easy access from paved road. Lots of parking.

name: Reaper Crew
text: Beautiful place to go home or just sit by the creek

name: Pearl D
text: Lots of hiking trails on the Pinhoti Trail. Moderate to strenious trails.

name: Chris Powers
text:
I give this 5 stars because it is just so unusual!
All of downtown Eufaula is full of interesting memorials and clever fun stuff! We had a great time on our own walking tour this particular Saturday in June 2021.

name: Anjelica Timms
text: Was so cool to see this. We didn't know the story of this fish so looked it up on the internet and found it to be a very interesting piece of history!

name: Donnie Shavers
text: It's a friendly town with great history of fishing and the only place I know of with a statue to honor a Bass.

name: William D. Johnson

name: Johnnie Bradt
text: This is a wonderful trail.  I ride my Yamaha Raptor 700.  Love the scenery and the trail is very well maintained.  There are lots of small water holes you have to watch out for; some have fairly deep ruts from ATVs.  I only ask, to whomever is in charge, that they make this one-way.  Please!!!  That is the only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5.  It NEEDS to be one-way; too risky for two-way traffic with the blind corners and elevation changes.  Make the stretch from the entrance to the start of the Red Trail one-way for those who do not want to do the full 13 miles, but the rest of the White Trail and the entire Red Train MUST be one-way

name: Frank Smith
text: Awesome. Rode both red and white routes. Lots of puddles though and hard pack. Would not recommend dirt biking after hard rain unless you like slipping around.

text: Nothing over 49 inches  can ride and the game wardens watch that very closely. Trails need to be cleared out for better riding quality. Not much there. Much better to go to stoney lonesome and other atv parks

name: Alexander Morris
text: Trails washed out. place has been closed for a few years but didnt see the sign up by the road that said closed untill we was leaving  and by the bathrooms says all trails are open on our way out the forest I flagged down the forest ranger to ask some questions about paying to fix it or fixing the trail myself only to be threatened to be taken to prison for just being on the property. I see several  kids riding fourwheeler and go carts etc on the public roads and this is one of the only places for local kids to ride. Something needs to be done

name: Lachlan Mac
text: Just opened again.  Will review later.

text: Love to ride the trails but I wish it was a little easier to find out if they are open or closed. Drove down while the government was shut down. I checked their website first but there was no information so I took a chance. Waisted my time. Gate was locked. Not to be unexpected. After the government reopened, I thought there would be no reason it would be closed. Checked the website again. Nothing mentioned about it being closed so off I go again. 1 hour later I was again disappointed by a locked gate...

name: Eric McQuiston
text: Not open.

text: It sure would be nice if they would update the website saying this place is STILL CLOSED.

name: Bradley Long
text: Had a AWESOME time. Loved the mud holes 😀 and the extra trail. Hope everyone fallows the rules and pay the small fee 👍👍😀

name: Myra Ball
text: Great views and scenery especially great in winter. Can use 4wheelers, off road motorcycles, bikes, and horse or hike. I would recommend only off road vehicles because of noise the horses get spooked by noise during heavy use times. Most times during the week, the area isn't crowded. I recommend not visiting after a heavy rain because the trails are slick.. Bankhead forest owns and manages the trails so follow all rules and stay on trails because the creeks need protecting from erosion damage. You may see a forest service law officer and get ticked for breaking the law by going off trail.

name: Matthew Christopher
text: Nice but gate is still closed..

text: Great for dirt bikes and four wheelers. Not too technical. 12 mile loop and 5 mile loop. 3 bucks per head. 50 inch max

text: This place is awesome, one big track and a smaller on that brakes off of the big track and meets up twords the end. 2 way traffic though, so look out

name: dennis robertson
text: Off-road motorcycle ride at Flint Creek today. Trail was in unusually good condition. There is some substantial wear due to erosion and usage, but fallen trees and storm damage has been managed. Met only one other user, a bicyclist, and we exchanged information concerning location and navigation, which I hope he found useful since he must have still been on the trail shortly afterwards when a storm arose.

text: Great hiking area ,might see a few people on the way or back,trail is clean,so the rest of you coming for a hike keep up the good work

name: Summer Kennedy
text: They really need a waterfall map! Wasted so much time looking for nothing. Nice camping at brush lake creek $5 a night.

name: Lindsey Hanna
text: Trail 201 was boring, nothing to see. We turned in 209 and the trail started to disappear. Then at the river it pointed for us to cross the Sipsey River, umm nope. We ended up off trail looking for the rest of the trail and this lost for over an hour and a half. We did find White Creek falls, which was pretty, but we were to stressed to take photos. Maybe another trail here is better,, but we will not be returning. Would not reccomend.

name: Kurt McDonald
text:
Randolph Wild trail taken by itself is bit of a boring 4 mile hike. But at the end, you're rewarded with two really nice waterfalls. To reach them you have to know they're there. The first one is easiest to get to. After about 3.5 miles from the trailhead you'll start down a steep descent. The trail will level off briefly at a small campsite. Turn around and take a few steps back the way you came and you'll see a fork that you probably walked right by without noticing. Take that fork to the left. In less than 5 minutes you'll be at a very nice waterfall in the wet season (early to mid spring, or after a significant rainfall)

The second waterfall is much harder to get to, but worth the effort. Go back to the campsite and continue going the way you were originally going. The trail gets much steeper. Yes, I said much steeper...so be careful and watch your footing. You'll soon come to a trail crossing. Take a left and follow that for a couple minutes. You'll come to a small creek that feeds into the larger Sipsey river on your right. Turn left at that creek. There's a trail there that is well defined in spots, and hard to follow in other spots. Just keep going with that creek on your right. Keep going until you reach the waterfall

name: Kathryn Smith
text: Beautiful hike along the creek but not ideal for kids under 10. Too long and too much climbing to get up to the waterfall. Not marked very well and lots of debris from falling trees. Witnesses two people get hurt from other groups.

name: matthew gibson
text: Great hike with my daughter

text: Well kept trails just wasn't what I was looking for.

name: Rebecca Rideout
text: easy to navigate, not a large space. well marked

name: Robin Bierworth
text: This place is wonderful 😊 They have many shops inside where you can find art, sweets and that special something. They also give the opportunity for local artists to come out and set up a tent/booth every Saturday! It's a great way to spend the day or even a few hours 😉. Definitely recommend this place 👍👍

name: Vic R
text: I enjoy visiting and browsing the vendors shops and checking out the art exhibits featuring local artists. The exhibits rotate so you will see new work often. There are a few good food options on site. They do outdoor concerts here as well; plenty of things for the family

name: Maria Lechtreck
text: This is such a wonderful and remarkable place.  But when I visited on the Saturday of the Memorial Day weekend 2021, along with tons of other visitors, it was disappointing that so few artists were in their studios to meet the visitors and share their stories and sell their creations.  I hope the artists will soon transition into a much faster recovery from COVID.

name: Davida Holiday
text: There are so many things to see, do, and taste at the Lowe Mill! I would recommend that you go on a Saturday (unless you are going for food, treats, or drinks then when they are open anytime is fine, because things right now (probably due to focus) are not really hopping on other days. Everything you see is eye candy! And oh my word, it is so worth it! Great place to take pictures as well!!! So go and soothe your soul with the art and satiate your taste buds with great did and yummy treats!

name: Aaron D. Lee
text: Huntsville staple. Went to shows there back in the early aughts and it is astounding how much it has grown. Check out Guadalupe's pottery (world-class) and Pizelles for some amazing (but definitely upscale-priced) chocolates, coffee, and Italian-style sodas.

name: Sue sad
text: Me and hubby checking out the art nice place to pick up things for the home plenty of  vendors to choose from outside and in try the tea 😋❣

name: Wendy Boustani
text: Really fun and eclectic maker shops. Good on-site eatery. Wall art and public areas are interesting to wander through. Highly recommend for local residents but especially as a pleasant low-key activity to bring out-of-town relatives.

name: Susan Wilke
text: We loved walking around and seeing the artists.  The dragon themed coffee shop was so fun.  Also loved Calvin Hubbard's pottery -- a must see on ground floor of building with dinosaur entrance.  He had many decorative and functional items.  We got a beautiful bowl & mug for a very reasonable price.  💖😊 He was also very friendly and fun to talk to with many years experience making pottery.

name: Debra Jeffery
text: Only visited the first floor, and the outside  areas. Next will be the 2nd floor. My first visit to the Mill, Awesome!  Soo much Talent, Thank you everyone for sharing.

text: An incredible location.  A.grand event space.

name: Kayra Dunn
text: Love the atmosphere.  Unique places to eat.  Very different to the usual food.  Got Orchard Peach tea.  Very good.  Follows the safety rules with mask and distancing.

text: Amazing food. Amazing art. Exciting activities. 10/10. Don't forget to visit the Dragon Forge Cafe!

text: This is SUCH a cool place!!! So much to see, I didn't have enough time! Can't wait to go back!

name: Lindsay Richer
text:
Beautiful location and building. The outside vendors were sparse and many of the inside vendors were closed. But I can presume this is due to the lingering effects of social distancing.

Our lunch from Poftà Bunà was AMAZING, the tea from Piper & Leaf was outstanding, and sitting outside was perfect.

name: Brandon Whaley
text: A fun place to do all kinds of things. Great for the family as well.

name: C B
text: The Mill is a phenomenal place. No matter who you are and what your interests are,..you can be at home at the mill. The Artists are awesome to shop with and talk to, the Events are Great. Its definitely a place that can enrich you and broaden your spectrums. I love the mill Alone, with My Husband, with my Kids, with my Friends.

name: Hismione Tremblay
text: Over all, a rather nice assortment of artistic venues and store fronts.  Two of the stairwells smell of bat guano due to the bats that inhabit them, which makes me wonder about health code violations due to all the diseases bats can carry, such as rabies for example.   The only elevator we could find was a service use only, not public use.  This would seem to make the building less accessible for those who might need assistance or who have strollers, which we did today.

name: Ryan S
text: Really enjoy going and walking around, looking at all the shops. Lots of amazing artists. A wonderful place to support local. Green pea press on the first floor and Artimaps on the third floor are a couple of my favorite places to visit! Great places to eat, like "The Happy Tummy". Can spend a couple hours here enjoying the beautiful surroundings. Lots of murals and art work throughout the building.

name: James Franklin
text: A real variety of things to see a lot of Talent on display well worth going to

name: Kyle Gott
text: This place is freaking sweet. We went last summer so a lot of places were closed due to COVID. I am looking forward to going this summer to see it with everything open. So many neat local artists and companies there. It’s a very old building so it’s cool how they repurposed it but it still has some of the old structure vibes.

name: Joe Masters
text: This place is so cool. I wish we had something like this at home. It's worth a trip to Huntsville just to go shop here. And bring the dog!

text: Fantastic place to see, buy, and learn to make art, along with meeting artists, and watching their processes. Unique food and drink. Diversity and acceptance.

text: Always a great place to go enjoy some quiet and walk around. Plenty of amazing artists to visit in their studios, and lots of good food and drink!

name: melissa
text: My children and I LOVE Lowe mill. We always make it a point to go to Dragon's Cafe each time we go.The raspberry Danish? Cookies are so delicious! We get them everytime. We've been trying different teas and coffees on the menu and haven't been disappointed yet. Lowe mill is just such a unique and fun place. We could spend hours walking the halls and looking at all the artwork and different shops.

name: Dylan Clark
text: You can never have a bad time at Lowe Mill. There's always something to see or do, and every visit manages to be a unique experience even after a dozen trips. Definitely a great place to spend your day & money at - especially for supporting the local community.

name: Abster_ Abbs
text: It's so beautiful there! One of my favorite places to go! Love seeing all the different art and even seeing some of the artist work!

name: Shannon Boyd
text: Amazing Arts and Custom Crafts venue. Individual artists' offerings in a wonderful venue ripe for exploring.  Come when you have plenty of time to explore all three floors. There are even food offerings to keep you fueled.

text: The people working there are very very very rude!! You had an employee walking around yelling at people to put on their mask ( which they were taking prom pictures) and told a grown man that he should know better and called him Sassy ... I will Never step foot on this property again.

Amazing space with lots to see. It has a metropolitan vibe that reminds me of New York and Miami's Art Basel, without the crowds of course.

Super enjoyable experience!

text: I really enjoy this venue, the atmosphere, and the food is okay. Most of the staff are pretty cool; however, the bartenders are not that friendly with exception of one who is really great! Not sure we'll ever go back since as this is the second time it's been like this.  Christmas is in 5 weekss so you'd think they'd want to make some money. Best part about the trip was the nice gentleman running the elevator.

Overall, a fun and eclectic experience nut one I only need occassionally.

text:
We set up to sell our jewelry on Saturdays. I am disappointed that there are not more customers people buying to support the artists but the exposure is awesome and we enjoyed networking with other artists and the art community. The only people who bought our art we're from out of town. Get out there Huntsville and support the arts better! Bobby is a killer hairstylist and the food is awesome. Great place to take kids if your looking for something to do in Huntsville.
Lowe Mill is a great place and a must see!

name: Beth Taylor
text: What a fun way to #buylocal! There's really something for everyone, whether you're trying to find a unique gift for a friend or just would like to try some fresh kombucha this is the place for you!

name: Rita Whatley
text:
First time to visit. Was interesting
To see all the different  art . Never been ?.worth giving it a once over.

text: Beautiful building with lots of fun things to do. I love the STEAM center there and I'm sad to see it go. Still a fun place to go even without the STEAMworks.

name: Harper W. Avent
text: Always a fun place to go for art, food, drinks, or jsut to walk around and hang out. There are so many different stores and vendors here. It seems like there is always something going on around the mill. It never gets old!

name: Stephanie Schrenk
text: There is so much to do and discover at lowe mill! There is always rotating art exhibits so there's always new art to look at, I love going into the artist studios and seeing their stuff for sale and the amazing things they create, and also there are delicious restaurants and an adorable cat cafe. There's also cool things to do like take classes and go to events, so there is always something that you will like or something that you will want to get into at lowe mill.

name: kimbolinarino
text: Important epicenter of art for the greater huntsville community. Has grown tenfold since it's humble beginnings as mostly a venue for local obscure bands and makers, as well as photographers in the early days with just a few anchored shops. Now has studios on every floor, restaurants, a community garden, shops, concerts, classes, all kinds of really awesome stuff and people under one roof. Cultural jewel of Huntsville.

name: Alex P
text: Cool atmosphere, lots of interesting products and services. A great time whether you're going just to walk around or to attend an event or festival.

name: Heather Whitmore
text: Lowe Mill is a great place to find unique gifts and decor for your home. I love supporting the local artists and enjoy their art classes, shows,  and restaurants. We went the other night to grab dinner and watch the "concert on the dock".  The weather was gorgeous and everyone was super friendly.  Had a great time and plan to go again next Friday.

name: Dan P
text: Fun place to hang out, appreciate creativity and art, I would also recommend as an option to anyone looking for a place to buy gifts.

name: Chloe C
text: One of my favorite places in Huntsville. I love all the artists here, whether current or artists that have left. I am biased though seeing as I basically grew up here. Lowe Mill offers some of the most fun events like Comic Con, concerts on the dock, and more. 10/10 would go again

name: Emaley Thomas
text: Absolutely wonderful facility & several excellent art galleries, shops, tea shop, and eateries. Gorgeous grounds & is filled with wonderful souls. Truly one 9f my favorite spots

name: Christy Lang
text: Love the outdoor spaces that are used for community events such as concerts & drive-in movies. Also like walking through the building to see local artists & vendors with their wares. It's quirky & fun.

name: Joanna DeAtley
text: Wonderful place full of amazing art and amazing people.  You'll find anything and everything here from sculptures to paintings to jewelry and more.   There are fantastic spots for food and drink as well.  The whole place is dog friendly and many of the artists adore having dogs visit. It's a great place for a family day.

name: Christopher Hall
text: Im a strong supporter of small business but was told several times I looked like I didn't belong there or I probably didn't have enough money to even be shopping in several of the shops will not be back unless these people can fix there overall attitude thinking they're better than everyone else.

text: Great wholesome fun for the whole family. Perfect for a date night too. Love this place. Huntsville is lucky to have a place like this.

You owe it to yourself to check this spot out,especially if you are in the Huntsville area. Hope you all enjoy it as much as I have

name: kimbolinarino
text: Important epicenter of art for the greater huntsville community. Has grown tenfold since it's humble beginnings as mostly a venue for local obscure bands and makers, as well as photographers in the early days with just a few anchored shops. Now has studios on every floor, restaurants, a community garden, shops, concerts, classes, all kinds of really awesome stuff and people under one roof. Cultural jewel of Huntsville.

name: Alura Garrison
text:
This is not only a place that supports local artists, but they also host many fun and helpful events like the A New Leash On Life adoption event/celebration! This is where Todd found his furever family!!!! ❤️❤️❤️❤️
There are some awesome local artists inside, too - gifts for men, women, kids, you name it, and there's probably an artist of that genre there.  Also, Happy Tummy has the BEST lunch foods ever. I used to eat there all the time when I worked at the genomics company that used to be on the other side.
I hear The Chef's food truck outside is fabulous too.

name: Essie Carpenter
text: One of my favorite creative spaces. Great for every member of the family!!!

name: Streeter Michael
text: Pizzells is awesome very good and out of the box chocolate. What a unique way to do a smores

name: susan glandon
text: Such a great place, with a variety of food, dessert, and shopping!

name: Chris Pittson
text: Nice to walk and look around and shop.

name: Jk R
text: Awesome place, great artists just beware the hipsters

name: Tara W.
text: Loved all the local art. And studios there!

name: Joanna DeAtley
text: Wonderful place full of amazing art and amazing people.  You'll find anything and everything here from sculptures to paintings to jewelry and more.   There are fantastic spots for food and drink as well.  The whole place is dog friendly and many of the artists adore having dogs visit. It's a great place for a family day.

name: Erik Walsh
text: Cool art spot with tons to check out.

name: brodie lowery
text: Such a wonderful place! Great shops, restaurants,entertainment and art. There is something for everyone in the family.

name: Jenn Ryan
text:
If you haven't had the chance to visit this place then you are really missing out in one of the hidden gems of Huntsville Alabama. There is absolutely something for everyone here, from one of kind art pieces, to classes, to chocolates, whiskey, ice cream, coffee, sandwiches and painted pieces for your favorite boardgame. Each time I am here I find a new corner to explore, a new food truck to enjoy or a new tea from the tea shop. I cannot wait for my next visit.

If you happen here make sure you check out their live schedule because sometimes there are bands playing, or maybe a poet or two. You never know what you find and where in the Lowest Mill you might find it.

Art, chocolates and tea pictures attached so you can see what I am talking about. Piper and Leaf...I highly recommend everything on the menu. A good start for a good shopping trip.

name: Tim Edwards
text: Plenty of parking.   Little difficult to find.   Lots of great artists and lots of walking.. several restaurants.

name: Joey Ellerbee
text: Liked getting lost in this place. Very cool.

name: MV Freeman
text:
This is a fabulous place with wonderful artist studios, a confection shop, coffee shop, tea shop and a Mediterranean place-- but the food is the side bar (all of it outstanding)- it's the art, painting, pottery, mixed media, jewelery places which display the wonderful talent in this area. Well worth the visit.
Note: nothing really opens until 12 weekdays (tea/coffee open earlier), and I am unsure about the weekends.

name: KYLE GOOS
text: This place is awesome! Haven't been back in a while , but can't wait to bring the family again. There's something there for everyone

name: Bona Indraputra
text: Great place to hang out and meet

name: Sean Hogan
text: Great cafe/ coffeehouse.  I had the minnie peanut butter cake and iced latte, it was delicious! I will love to swing by here again next time I'm in town.

name: Elizabeth Douglas
text: Fantastic venue! We loved attending the Snowball held here and look forward to other events at this location. The space was really well used and seemed like the kind of place that could be easily transformed depending on the type of event taking place. Loved the fact admission was only $10 per person. Parking was easy as the lot was spacious. Looking forward to visiting again.

name: Jerome A Powell
text: Housed in an old mill facility, Lowe Mill is the country's largest privately owned arts center. Artists of all genres have studios here and on Saturdays, the Artist Market is set up for one-time sellers to hawk their wares. The creaky wood floors hint at the building's age while modern art remind visitors of our space program ties. It's a great place to visit on Saturdays to roam and shop.

name: Myra L Walker-Williams
text: This is truly a hidden gem!! I was there for a photo shoot of my daughter with Huntsville's own Dokk Savage Photographer. He found a venue to fit exactly what she was needing. I'm planning another trip back, because you cannot possibly take in all of this awesomeness in a day. I suggest three days minimum.

name: Bryan Singer
text: This has been a real joy to watch develop over the years.  Don't miss on your trip to Huntsville!!

name: Deborah Holt
text: Benefit at Lowe Mill old cotton mill transformed into a music art venue welcomes the public all ages and brings together a community of artists weirdos and love

name: Nathan Stewart
text:
I went during comic con, but apart from the event vendors, the regular shop vendors have a ton of things to offer. The chocolate shop has amazing flavors, and there are several food places that looked delicious. We also swung by several art shops which had a lot of interesting items, and picked up some miniatures. There are several studios that offer electronic camps/lessons and art lessons, there's even a cigar guitar class.

Tl;dr; go check this place out, you'll probably find something you like.

name: Emmanuel Leonard
text: I came here on a Saturday towards the end of the day so a lot of the shops were closed. I still enjoyed my time walking around and looking at the various art pieces they had displayed. I would go again but probably in the early afternoon.

name: Mike G
text: Tons of small local artistry shops that cover a myriad of specialties along with some great little food spots. Wonderful way to waste a day and support local artists.

name: Tammy Wolfe
text:
The Halloween candy trail was great was only about 6 cars left handout candy but my grandbaby was still happy  about it
Thank to who all were there and lowe mill for doing this

name: Hector Murrieta
text: Great place to hang out, see art, listen to music, places to paint, etc. Definitely worth a visit (or a dozen).

name: S Clay
text: I love this place, many different types of art. Spent hours looking, and we even bought a small painting. Found a small place to eat and spent most of the afternoon looking!

name: Rosemary Davidson
text: So many neat little shops and artists. A treasure in the community.

name: John Beck (BeekrJR)
text: A great area for local talent to share their products and passions

name: Deitrick Smart
text: New more food places.

name: Kayla VanEtten
text: I love Lowe Mill it's gotten so much bigger! I remember when we used to call it the flying monkey and go to the market on Saturdays. I've recently purchased tickets to an "R rated magic show" there one night which was great. I also went to yule y'all and will definitely be back soon! I love so many things about this place.

name: Debora Pederse
text: Creative art center. Many talented artisans. I liked that one can learn various crafts. If you like the weird and artsy angle, plenty of that.  Some great gourmet food and chocolate confections. An experience worth checking out.

name: John Muhlhauser
text: Very cool place to spend your time in the weekend. It's free to get it, and there are many things to do and observe different kind of arts.

name: Kimberly Bowie
text: Very fun artsy environment. Comfortable Place to chill and eat. Great place to host fashion events when additional lighting is considered. Respectful, helpful staff.

name: Brian White
text: Great wholesome fun for the whole family. Perfect for a date night too. Love this place. Huntsville is lucky to have a place like this.

name: Brandie Robinson
text: I love this place!

name: Tonya Sitko
text: Very unique collection of artist studios in an old mill/factory.  Attempts have been made to retain the factory vibe/feel.  Wear good walking shoes when you visit, and leave plenty of time to explore, eat pizza, eat a popsicle, and shop!

name: D'Arcy Burgess
text: Love this place! Grab a vegan/vegetarian meal from Chef Will's while you're there! Amazing food!

name: Robert Rivera
text:
Simply, awesome and genuine ambiance for the creative mind! I wish there would be properties like this in Miami area.

Lots of options of work and talent to look & feel the work being done and sold.

The best environment I have experienced in the US.  This is a must visit! For the whole family.

Pros:
- great location in Huntsville
- ample parking
- good for the true coffee fanatic (Alchemy)!
- spaces are well laid out, studios and offices have great light and window openings to see from inside the walkway
- halls have ample walking space
- plenty of excellent food options

Cons
- none found yet!

Simply love it! Will be a definite regular customer!

name: Lapping PoofPoof
text: Nice knit stuffed kitties

name: Sally MacDonald
text: Because of covid, not much was open.  Very few artists working.  Also it was confusing to find your way around.  The diagrams on the walls were not very helpful.

name: Pitts Burgher
text: Everyone should go and see all of the local artist and crafters who have their stores set up there. Food and drink are available. Check out 5 Points Elements. Great store.

name: John VanAntwerp
text: Really nice artist venue.  I wish more places had been open.

name: Vanessa Bowser
text: Great space and really awesome vendors. We visited on a Saturday and there were artists there at working on projects. Many were very visible, friendly, and eager to discuss their work. A few food vendors located inside and there is an art supply store! I will definitely go back for another visit!

name: Sandra Yokem
text: First time there. Took my 12 year old granddaughter and WOW we had a great time

name: Gary Sheffer
text: Great eclectic environment.  Totally chill with fabulous art and good food stalls.

name: Stephen Walls
text: Hard to beat the variety of entertainment you can get for free at Lowe Mill. The drive-in night was an interestkng mix of dark comedy short films.

name: Beth Taylor
text: What a fun way to #buylocal! There's really something for everyone, whether you're trying to find a unique gift for a friend or just would like to try some fresh kombucha this is the place for you!

name: Dominique Brooks
text: Chef Will is food is Amazing

name: Kathy Edgar
text: Perfect place to fill your day. Make sure you check out the following: Piper and Leaf Tea, Chris Wade at Studio 202, White Rabbit Records, and Pizzelle's Confections.

name: Rachel Haggard
text: Love this place, wish they had this up North

name: Nathan Stewart
text:
I went during comic con, but apart from the event vendors, the regular shop vendors have a ton of things to offer. The chocolate shop has amazing flavors, and there are several food places that looked delicious. We also swung by several art shops which had a lot of interesting items, and picked up some miniatures. There are several studios that offer electronic camps/lessons and art lessons, there's even a cigar guitar class.

Tl;dr; go check this place out, you'll probably find something you like.

name: Debora Pederse
text: Creative art center. Many talented artisans. I liked that one can learn various crafts. If you like the weird and artsy angle, plenty of that.  Some great gourmet food and chocolate confections. An experience worth checking out.

name: Kimberly Midkiff
text: Lots of fine art and entertainment.

name: Tonya Sitko
text: Very unique collection of artist studios in an old mill/factory.  Attempts have been made to retain the factory vibe/feel.  Wear good walking shoes when you visit, and leave plenty of time to explore, eat pizza, eat a popsicle, and shop!

name: Justin Malone
text: I rarely get to enjoy the Mill due to my own conflicting work hours.  However, it never disappoints!  It's always an adventure here.

name: Brandie Robinson
text: I love this place!

name: Mark Stevenson
text: Great place...always something new.

name: D'Arcy Burgess
text: Love this place! Grab a vegan/vegetarian meal from Chef Will's while you're there! Amazing food!

name: Kaylee Powell
text: Such a fun, eclectic environment, and a great place to learn, take classes, or observe the creative process. Suzy's is great, and so is the happy tummy restaurant! I'll be back!

name: Claudette Patton
text: I love it here

name: Callie Livesay
text: This place is amazing for all of the cool things you can do there! Saturdays they have artist markets with local artists selling their wares, plus the permanent shops they have there. Lots of good places to eat also. They host comedy shows, music shows, even circus sideshows! It's really the most unique arts place in Huntsville

name: Thomas Garner
text: Multitude of things to do here, They have everything from pop up artist shops to a chocolate store with amazing coffee. Perfect place for a date or just a fun day trip if you are near huntsville.

name: Tamyra Sampson
text: We took pictures here.  Its a beautiful place for this.

name: Charles Wildman
text: First time at Lowe Mill, everyone should go check it out

name: Crisa Slusher
text: Get chocolate! Not only is it stunning, it's equally delicious. Great destination! Ride the elevator. Swing on the 2nd floor. Find the giant metal bug. Buy art. Have a glorious time.

name: Donna
text: Saturdays at the Mill are the best!

name: Katelyn G
text: We've been on both a weekday and Saturday. The variety of artists are nice with lots of beautiful and some unique art. There were some artists who were closed both days which was difficult to navigate if you wanted to visit them. But definitely worth visiting and taking any out of towners who are into art.

name: Roberto Fuschi
text: Really cool concept; art stores, pinball machine store ..good lunch too

name: Paul Godsey
text: Good place to look and explore

name: John Smith
text: Saturday night obscure films were exactly what they sound like: Saturday night and obscure. Really enjoyed the tradition of honking after a film finished to show interest, did not enjoy pressure to honk when I personally didn't enjoy a short film.

name: Cameron Page
text: So creative! Amazing arts center

name: bev bauer
text: Wonderful artwork friendly people in a historical environment. Not in every city rare.

name: PATRICIA MENDEZ
text: I fell in love with Lowe the first time I visited it. I sold my baked goods at the Flying Monkey Arts gig on Saturday’s. I no longer live in HSV but the 4 years I lived there we always spent time at the Mill. I’ve heard that Lowe Mill is home to the largest arts facility in the US. Go Huntsville! The swing dancing in the theater was always the cat’s pajamas!  Piper Leaf provides the best tea by far! You can buy a mason jar and get your tea it every time you visit Piper Leaf. There  is so much to do... concerts on the dock... good eats...beautiful artwork...cool studios... funky shops. I can go on but it’s best if y’all check it out y’all selves. I miss my beloved Lowe Mill. Guess I’ll have to visit soon.

name: Cheyenne Michelli
text: My second home. I have made many dear friends here over the years and I wouldn't trade the memories I have there for anything. Highly recommend! The community is extremely diverse

name: Nyki Pastuszka
text: Instead of reading my thoughts, you should already be here exploring what huntsville artists have to offer. As accessible as this hub is... you got no excuse for not visiting at least ONCE while you're in town.... and if you're a native I hope that you're only reading this because you're about to leave your own awesome review!

name: Barb Graybeal
text:
First visit to Mountain Valley Pizzeria.  We are now permanent customers!  This will be part of each visit to H'ville.  The pizza and the bread were made exactly  the way we love.  It is not your
corner pick up and run pizza.  It's a completely new experience.

name: Jose Olivero
text: Sent to have my bicycle check. Very helpful staff.

name: Jacob Benning
text: A bit out of the way, but a trip worth noting for artists or someone looking to burn an hour or two.  There's a decent amount of parking, so no worries about mile-long hikes.  Despite the rustic conditions, and an odd bat-related smell in one of the stairwells (as noted on a painted wall acknowledging the offending smell) the experience was an enjoyable one.  On each floor, the halls are lined with studios for independent artists, each as unique as a fingerprint.  Would happily return for the art and the wide range of food ranging from tea to shaorma.

name: ladyrob4110
text: I love the record store

name: Michael Pukish
text: Well, there are some quaint places that individually do specific foods, desserts, cafe stuff right, but overall there's something not quite aligned with the hype.. For certain, all the prices are more than a bit high. And it's not their fault, but I've never been there when it's "hopping with excitement".  I like the buildings and the ambience, but maybe things pick up and it takes on a new character during special events. I haven't made it there for that yet, and maybe that will change my mind.

name: HLLW
text: All the local art was probably the most fascinating thing, very calming area to be in plus the multitudes of mini businesses in the building were interesting to go by.  I would highly recommend the paper flower shop (can't remember the name of it off the top of my head) but definitely go there for a cute gift for your S.O.  They can last several years.

name: Callie Livesay
text: This place is amazing for all of the cool things you can do there! Saturdays they have artist markets with local artists selling their wares, plus the permanent shops they have there. Lots of good places to eat also. They host comedy shows, music shows, even circus sideshows! It's really the most unique arts place in Huntsville

name: Tamyra Sampson
text: We took pictures here.  Its a beautiful place for this.

name: Winston Howard
text: Love the location and the hold vibe was great. I could see this place as a causal hangout and for dates

name: Claudette Patton
text: I love it here

name: Donna
text: Saturdays at the Mill are the best!

name: Paul Godsey
text: Good place to look and explore

name: Christi Doyle
text: One of my favorite places.

name: Aimee Minter
text: Love love love this place! There's always something to do. Shows, comedians, dancing, zumba classes, concerts, food, different kid friendly  events, painting, art. The building itself is even interesting. The property is nicely cleaned up. Lots of parking. There's 3 floors you can climb the stairs or ride the elevator. They have a farmers market on Saturday's You can explore the inside buy art, homemade jewery, all kinds of pretty things, baked goodies, there a couple photo studios, a comic book area, a few restaurants, even get a cartoonist draw a picture of you.

name: Aimee Minter
text: Love love love this place! There's always something to do. Shows, comedians, dancing, zumba classes, concerts, food, different kid friendly  events, painting, art. The building itself is even interesting. The property is nicely cleaned up. Lots of parking. There's 3 floors you can climb the stairs or ride the elevator. They have a farmers market on Saturday's You can explore the inside buy art, homemade jewery, all kinds of pretty things, baked goodies, there a couple photo studios, a comic book area, a few restaurants, even get a cartoonist draw a picture of you.

name: Jacob Benning
text: A bit out of the way, but a trip worth noting for artists or someone looking to burn an hour or two.  There's a decent amount of parking, so no worries about mile-long hikes.  Despite the rustic conditions, and an odd bat-related smell in one of the stairwells (as noted on a painted wall acknowledging the offending smell) the experience was an enjoyable one.  On each floor, the halls are lined with studios for independent artists, each as unique as a fingerprint.  Would happily return for the art and the wide range of food ranging from tea to shaorma.

name: Nyki Pastuszka
text: Instead of reading my thoughts, you should already be here exploring what huntsville artists have to offer. As accessible as this hub is... you got no excuse for not visiting at least ONCE while you're in town.... and if you're a native I hope that you're only reading this because you're about to leave your own awesome review!

name: Denise Marsh
text: Spectacular history tied into Lowe Mill. Each place we visited had friendly, helpful employees.

name: LaShonda Scott Robinson
text: A wonderful place for art lovers!

name: John Smith
text: Saturday night obscure films were exactly what they sound like: Saturday night and obscure. Really enjoyed the tradition of honking after a film finished to show interest, did not enjoy pressure to honk when I personally didn't enjoy a short film.

name: Christi Doyle
text: One of my favorite places.

name: Sara Hardin
text: My daughter is there this week with Hsv City Schools..Steam Works project!! We Love Lowe Mill!!

name: Damian Quattlebaum
text: Very artsy. Some really cool displays and shops. While it was entertaining, if there had been a few more dining options, we probably would've spent more time here. If you go, ride the one working elevator and get a quick dose of history about the building.

name: Christian Leach
text: One of the best places to go in Huntsville! They have a variety of shops and artist workspaces. There is a weekly artist market on the weekends filled with all sorts of neat stuff!

name: Justin Malone
text: I rarely get to enjoy the Mill due to my own conflicting work hours.  However, it never disappoints!  It's always an adventure here.

name: Lexy Senft
text: So stimulating to see so much art and the lenses through which others view the world. Lots of vegan options around when it comes to food. Poetry slams and live music. Easily one the best spots to visit in Huntsville.

name: Joy Goodloe
text: Limited art exhibits.

name: Elizabeth Niedfeldt
text: Very cool artist studios!  The history of the building is incredible with multiple floors and hallways! We went there trick-or-treating,  it was busy, but fun for my granddaughter! Would go again to listen to music....!

name: Winchester Jude
text: So much to see and activities to take part in. Many fun and inspiring events throughout the year. So many fine artists in one place. Arts & music abound.

name: Elizah Polard
text: This place has so much to offer to any artistry community. Love to go in here and just walk around. Will say I miss the vintage clothing store that was on the second level. My eyes are never dull in this place amazing art.

name: Hans Ruoss
text: Neat historic setting in old textile mill.  Packed with artisans of various trades, good food places, and some music.  Easy to navigate and very unique.

name: Jerome White
text: Great exhibits along with tons of awesome classes.

name: Darryl Gutierrez
text: I randomly found this on a web site when looking for things to do in Huntsville. Although I haven't experienced it yet, they host many types of outdoor concerts on the docks. The mill is home to many artist studios and plans are to open more soon. Every Saturday art is on display and for sale. Great husband and wife to girlfriend trip. The sandwich shop was good but SLOW. Still worth the wait but plan ahead and don't get in line when you are starving. I look for this to become really popular.

name: Abigail Hancock
text: I loved this place for years, so it was the perfect place for me to want to have my prom pictures taken. Except I heard rumors that they would be charging people and extortionate amount just to  let us in to take pictures with an iPhone.
